Award.AwardTitle: Identifying and Validating Interactive and Uncommon Characteristics of Retention and Success in Engineering Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project targets three significant gaps in the current state of knowledge relevant to engineering retention and success: 1) lack of knowledge on engineering retention and success characteristics based on interactive, concurrent effects of multiple factors, 2) lack of knowledge about engineering retention and success characteristics based on the modeling of variable relations that exist for some but not all values of variables or are different for different value ranges of variables, and 3) lack of knowledge about uncommon engineering retention and success characteristics of outlier students who do not fall into common characteristics of engineering retention and success. The project will employ the new Partial-Value Association Discovery (PVAD) algorithm to identify common and uncommon characteristics of engineering retention and success. This project is supported by NSF's EHR Core Research (ECR) program. The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.

New findings from this project will enrich the understanding and knowledge of engineering retention and success, in comparison with existing findings based on effects of individual variables and all-value variable relations. The intervention with an engineering counseling and tracking program to help students development of the newly identified engineering retention and success characteristics will be developed and implemented. The intervention effects on students will be observed and analyzed to validate the new findings of engineering retention and success characteristics. The identification and validation of new engineering retention and success characteristics will provide guidelines to help more students achieve engineering retention and success across the nation, thus broadening the participation of more students in engineering fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of this project includes new findings and knowlege about common and uncommon characteristics of student retention in engineering and life sciences after the first year in university. Not poor versus poor academic performance measured mainly by GPA in the first year in university is the most dominant common characteristic that separates a majority of students who stay in engineering and life sciences from a majority of students who leave engineering and life sciences. There are two types of uncommon students: students who have not poor academic performance but leave engineering and life sciences, and students who have poor academic performance but stay in engineering and life sciences. Race in terms of white students versus not-white students is a major characteristic of those uncommon students, as white students have more tendency to leave engineering and life sciences even with not poor academic performance in university, and not-white students have more tendency to stay in engineering and life sciences even with poor academic performance in university. Gender also plays a role among those uncommon students, as male students have more tendency to stay in engineering and life sciences even with poor academic performance. Students who are not honor students are less stable or vary more in the retention outcome, given their academic performance.

 

The intellectual merit of this project also includes new findings and knowledge about the use of various interventions by students for study/assistance in learning. The interventions include: class attendance, study using textbooks, interactions with professors/teaching assistants, advising/counselling, tutoring, study groups, peer mentoring, orientation camps, career center/career events, and coaching on mindsets and methods of learning and study/assistance, taking responsibility/control, and prioritizing for time and stress management. These interventions focus on helping students' learning and show their effectiveness in improving students' academic performance and thus retention. The results of the project also point out the need for interventions to motivate students' study drive of putting time and efforts into study and the need for interventions of study and learning assistance tailored to different types of study drive.

 

The broader impacts of new retention characteristics in engineering and life sciences and new insights into interventions for student retention are made by giving new guidelines to help more students achieve retention in engineering and life sciences across the nation, thus broadening the participation of more students in fields of engineering and life sciences. This in turn will broaden the participation, retention and success of students in engineering and life sciences, and will promote a healthy development and growth of human resources in the society, thus benefiting the public good and contributing to economic, social, and cultural vitality as well as health and well-being of local, regional and national communities.

 

The new data mining algorithm to discover multivariate data associations and software code of the algorithm fill in a big technology gap in existing machine learning and data mining techniques. The new algorithm and software code will help data scientists in many fields analyze data in these fields to gain new information and knowledge. Seven new sets of student data collected in this project can be used by many other data scientists to study STEM education and develop and validate new machine learning and data mining technologies.

 


Last Modified: 10/09/2020
Modified by: Nong Ye
